content: I encountered this pattern for the first time during a clash and had trouble understanding the 2nd step, adding the next character of the given character set. It would be really helpful to have some clarification on this point in the statement, specifically what is meant by the "next character."

Got it in reverse, it is very hard. I think the example 12345/5 would be great to add as a test case (not validator) because you can see the pattern clearer.
-o0|/4 is a great example but still a bit more difficult to read than 12345/5 which is clearer

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I approved it, the test cases can help the coder to figure out what he has to do to solve it.
It goes through String manipulation, one of the main concepts treated by the platform on each mode (puzzles, clash of code, bots...etc) which helps the coder to develop properly his/her intuitivity

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Interesting mathematical concept. The author has made the problem statement clear and added tests to make reverse mode possible, so it should work well in all game modes.

I seriously doubt this is possible in reverse.
Solution in Perl:
@a=<>=~/./g;$\=$\.$a[$i++].$\for 1..<>;print

If you remove the reverse mode I'll be happy to validate

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good quick puzzle. Not sure it suits reverse though.

Simple, adapted for CoC.
Quite challenging for reverse, but feasible.

I would add the following constraint:
n is not bigger than the number of letters in alphabet.

I also wonder if the word "alphabet" is well chosen, because a letter can appear multiple times in the "alphabet".
Thanks for the feedback! I added the constraint, but I'm not sure what to change the word "alphabet" to.
Hello! Thanks for the input. However, I do want Reverse mode for this clash, if possible. Do you think Reverse mode would be more doable if I modify some test cases or add easier ones?
Thank you so much! And thank you for your help as well.
Thank you for the feedback! I switched the test case and validator for that one.

Unless the person solving is already familiar with this type of pattern. It would still be next to impossible to figure out.

I doubt that would help that much.
To aid Reverse  mode I would start with AB/2, ABC/3, ABCD/4. After enough examples to figure out the fractal pattern, you can add the longer alphabets where not all letters get used.

Hello! Thanks so much for the suggestions! I've changed and switched around some of the test cases.

@selenae I've made the first few simpler, as you've implied, to try to help people figure out the pattern. Note I didn't do exactly what you did just so that it wouldn't be too simple.

@EmeraldBlackbird
Hi, I agree with anon42 that this is a very good problem, but reverse will be extremely difficult to solve unless you are already familiar with this pattern (I don't think many people are). I don't think selenae's suggestion is too simple for those of us who are unfamiliar, if anything I would include additional easy tests:

1234, 2 > 121
1234, 3 > 1213121
1234, 4 > 121312141213121

With the knowledge from other cases that 1234, 1 > 1 the pattern becomes clear for the unitiated.
Happy to approve this if you can resolve the reverse issue one way or another :)

@GPoll,

Hello, thank you so much for your wonderful feedback. I have made a few changes to the content and order of the test cases as well as the description statement. I'm trying to not make the clash too easy, so I hope these changes would be sufficient in helping people to find the pattern but not give it away. I have noticed that there are about 4 test cases with 3 as N but with different character sets. I'm hoping this is a good hint as to how the pattern works.

I think you can state that it is a given alphabet at step 2 in the step description as well. You don't always read the whole statement when you're going fast in a clash, so I think its important to state the same thing everywhere.

Other than that, this is a nice clash, might be too hard for reverse, but I think doable.

You could perhaps put it in more 'coder-friendly' language. Imperfect example:

The first iteration's output is the first character in a given set.
To generate the nth iteration's output :
1. Take the previous iteration's output.
2. Add the next character from the set.
3. Add the previous iteration's output.
Task: Print the ABACABA pattern from the nth iteration using the given set of characters.
